Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2008 08:21PM StaceyR wrote: Hi Kim, I just turned 34 and had a lumpectomy with SNB done yesterday.  My recovery is going really well and I feel good.  I had an MRI done a couple weeks before the surgery.  I'd heard the same thing, that you can get false-positives with MRIs, but in my case, that's giving me relief, since they didn't find anything else to be concerned about.  I hope it means the cancer won't be found in my lymph nodes.  I personally did not find the MRI unpleasant.  I closed my eyes and listened to the radio that they piped in on the headphones.  Sometimes the machine was so loud that it overpowered the music, but it was mostly bearable.  Oh, I also do not have a drain after my lumpectomy.  I hope you get the answers you're looking for. ~Stacey
Posts.Title: Drains & Time Off Work For Lumpectomy Kim32 Solihull

Posts.Content: StaceyR wrote: Help, I'm looking for input from anyone who has gone through this before.  I've already started chemo, but as part of my staging I had the usual array of tests.  Most have come back fine, but apparently there are some suspicious spots showing in the bone scan on some of my ribs (different ones on each side).  They say this could be the result of old injuries, but I'm kinda freaking out anyway.  I have to go for follow-up x-rays next week. Has anyone else had to deal with this type of thing?  Is this a common result? Dx 3/18/2008, IDC, Left, 1cm, Stage IA, Grade 3, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 4/22/2008 Lumpectomy: Left Chemotherapy 6/5/2008 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Ellence (epirubicin), Fluorouracil (5-fluorouracil, 5-FU, Adrucil), Taxotere (docetaxel) Radiation Therapy 10/5/2008 Breast Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Abnormal bone scan result - ribs StaceyR carole1

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2008 02:47PM StaceyR wrote: Carole, things turned out okay for me, with my xrays revealing no cancer in my ribs, so that was a huge relief to hear, especially before heading into another chemo session.  It's true that it's SO frustrating to have these additional stresses piled on to what we're already dealing with.  I hope you got a similar no-worry result as I did.
Posts.Title: Abnormal bone scan result - ribs StaceyR carole1

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2008 11:30AM StaceyR wrote: Thanks, ladies, I'm going to try not to worry about it too much.  I've been wracking my brain trying to remember any possible injury that I may have suffered throughout my life.  The time I got hit in the back with an ankle weight?  The time I got slammed into the sand trying to boogie-board? The one that's worrying me the most is the one I can't seem to account for - the *first* rib (way up under the collarbone?) on the left side.  That was my cancer side, so I'm pretty anxious to rule out bad news.  Man.  I thought I was having a bad week 'cause my hair's falling out...
Posts.Title: Abnormal bone scan result - ribs StaceyR carole1

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2008 08:12PM StaceyR wrote: I had my first good news yesterday and it made me surprisingly happy.  I met with my surgeon to discuss the results of my MRI and he revealed that I don't have any other problems besides my one known lump.  So we're all clear to proceed with the lumpectomy.  I was anxious about the results because I know MRIs are incredibly precise (to the point of having false positives), so it eased my mind so much to know that we're only battling one little bad guy.  It feels do-able.

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2008 07:30PM StaceyR wrote: I'm also part of the April surgery gang.  I am scheduled for lumpectomy with SNB on the 22nd.  Oh, and I turned 34 last week. Good luck tomorrow, Becca.
Posts.Title: Anyone having surgery in April?? ottawagirl wahine

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2008 08:04PM StaceyR wrote: My surgery went well yesterday.  I was a little bored waiting in the queue in the "day care" unit, but when it was finally my turn, it was lights out and I only woke up with a bit of pain.  They promptly drugged me up good and I've been feeling fine ever since.  I was surprised that it is under my arm where they took the lymph nodes that hurts worse than the lumpectomy site on my breast - I didn't think that was going to happen.  But all in all, not an unpleasant day all things considered. Now I cross my fingers and wait for my next results.
Posts.Title: Anyone having surgery in April?? ottawagirl wahine

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2009 12:24PM StaceyR wrote:
Posts.Title: MRI false negatives? worried4sis marie5890

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2008 11:43AM StaceyR wrote: CristiC, I know exactly how you feel, just watiting for that day when the hair is supposed to fall.  I was so restless and frustrated by day 10, and venting about it to anyone who would listen.  It's almost like you get to the point where you hope (or think) that it won't happen, because there's such a delay.  Maddening. And sadly, I did not handle it well when the day finally came.  On the other hand, I adjusted pretty well afterwards.  I was like, "hey, I'm not so scary, so what I'm bald".  I hope that you are not too upset by it - it sucks, but we all deal. Now I'm part of the crowd waiting for it all to come back.  Last tx on Sept 18, and just now getting some action on my eyebrows and lashes.  I'm aiming for Christmas before I expect to be comfortable enough to go wig-less. I lurk here more than post, so I told my bf about the 3-month brow/lash phenomenon and Otter's theory that it synchronizes their life cycle.  He suggested some pre-emptive plucking to force some of them off-cycle, or something.  I'm still contemplating whether this would be a good idea!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2008 01:24PM StaceyR wrote: I totally fit this category too.  I was feeling overwhelmingly desperate in the situation I was in, living with a boyfriend I wasn't sure about, in a new city I was having difficulty adjusting to, and feeling so stuck and helpless to change things that it kept me up at night.  For months.  Ugh.  I do tend to blame myself more than I probably should, but it means I work really hard to change as many of the conditions that gave rise to the cancer as possible.
Posts.Title: Does desperation play a role in developing breast cancer? HeatherBLocklear dlb823

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2008 04:33AM StaceyR wrote: I'm so sorry to hear about your preliminary results, inlimbo - I totally know what you're saying about not causing pain for your family.  That has been my biggest worry about this ordeal.  At least now you've got some initial answers and you can move ahead with the next step.  Your focus right now should be on yourself; your family will probably surprise you with how supportive they are - that's what I've concluded for myself when I imagine what my outcome might be.  You are in my thoughts.
Posts.Title: Final results in-good and not so good Iamblessed LaughingWater

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2008 07:47AM StaceyR wrote: Angela, I wanted to chime in as another 34-year-old on the same road (somewhat).  My IDC was 1.4 cm and I had negative nodes, so I was really hoping they would only recommend rads for me.  It was hard and scary to face the possibility of chemo.  With any invasive component, and our "young" age, they have to be aggressive.  If you decide to do the chemo, know that you will be okay.  And let me say, you'll feel like a rockstar when you come out the other end just fine.

Posts.Title: Biopsy @ 3:30 today CKCSLover CKCSLover

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2008 07:37AM StaceyR wrote: It is a relief in a way to read these posts and hear that others are experiencing something like what I'm feeling these days (not that I wish this on anyone).  I am 33 years old.  Two months ago, I found a lump, went for a mammogram and ultrasound, and have been waiting (too long, it seems) to get in for a biopsy.  My biopsy appointment is on Monday and I'm getting more nervous by the hour, even though I won't even know anything for "4 to 10 business days" afterwards, they tell me.  My radiology report said I had a "hypoechoic lobulated nodule measuring 1.1 x 1 x 0.7 cm which has some calcifications".  And my rating is BIRADS 4B - "suspicious abnormality".  I feel so alone in dealing with the stress, because I made the decision not to share this with my family until I know something definitive.  As others have said, this forum is a blessing.

Posts.Title: Waiting for Biopsy jmyers Justine

Posts.Content: May 28, 2008 05:14AM StaceyR wrote: I'm relieved to read that other people have had port pain, 'cause I had mine put in yesterday and there were "complications" during the procedure. I am having a hard time distinguishing between pain from the port and pain in my lung.  Right now it hurts a LOT. Apparently in about 1% of cases, the surgeon nicks the pleural membrane around the lung, and wouldn't you know it, yesterday was my lucky day, and I suffered from a partial lung collapse - a "pneumothorax".  I had to have a portable chest tube put in, so I came home from the hospital with tubing taped all down my arm that allows the air to escape from around my lung while it repairs itself. Last night the pain was so bad I took myself back to the ER.  The people putting the chest tube in were about to leave for the day and kind of neglected to tell me what kind of pain to expect, didn't give me anything for pain, and didn't really explain how to care for the tube.  In my partially sedated and frozen state yesterday I failed to realize things would get worse before getting better. Anyway, since I'm awake at 4:30 in the morning I thought I would share and vent a little.  This is not cool.  I really hope the Percocet kicks in soon!
Posts.Title: Port-a Cath pain? TinaLee Kicks

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2008 11:00AM StaceyR wrote: Hello others who wait, I'm here to unload a bit.  I had my biopsy this morning and although it was not painful, I still found it to be very stressful and unpleasant.  I think the reality of it was too much for me.  Then I started getting woozy from the freezing in my breast (and the mounting anxiety) so they stopped after taking 3 samples instead of the 4 they intended.  The doctor assured me they had enough, though. LaughingWater, I know what you mean about the mood music.  It was so quiet in the room I told the assistant they needed music - she obliged me by putting on the radio, but I was wishing I had my iPod blasting in my ears to distract me. I was supposed to go to work right after the appointment but I am taking a couple hours for myself before I go in.   I just want to cry right now.  Results in 7 to 10 days - argh.  Welcome to Canada: free healthcare but you might have to wait.
Posts.Title: Waiting for Biopsy jmyers Justine

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2008 11:45AM StaceyR wrote: Me too, Jackie.  My doctor's office called me this morning and my heart started pounding and hands started shaking.  But I had an appointment scheduled long ago for a physical next week, so they were just calling to remind me.  I suppose they may have my results by then anyway, but man alive, I'm a bit of a basket case. My wound is now a lovely yellow with purple accents, but seems to be healing well.  It's less sore every day.
Posts.Title: Waiting for Biopsy jmyers Justine

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 10:13PM StaceyR wrote: Laughingwater, I felt a bit of pain on the second grab, actually.  Felt like it went a little farther than the other two.  But I haven't had much pain today.  They told me to wear my "tightest" bra afterwards, but I have tiny breasts and my lump is right beside my sternum (8 o'clock) so there's not really any pressure on the area.  I only felt it when I was sleeping - I usually hug a pillow to my chest, but it was a little raw last night.  I really hope we all get the results we want, and quickly.  I think the waiting is going to kill me. Good luck tomorrow Dottie. I hope it's over quickly.
Posts.Title: Waiting for Biopsy jmyers Justine

Posts.Content: May 28, 2008 06:35PM StaceyR wrote: Thanks, catlover, for your advice.  I'm glad to hear I'm not the first to endure this.  It's funny you mention the sleeping position thing - I even specifically asked the doctor that and they said it wouldn't make a difference, but I definitely feel better in the vertical position.  I'll be happy when I'm done with miscellaneous surgical procedures, healing wounds, and complications!  Let's just get on with this chemo. ;)
Posts.Title: Port-a Cath pain? TinaLee Kicks

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2008 03:28PM StaceyR wrote: I had the same reaction to the prescribed dosage, totally freaked, was sure there was a mistake, but nurse confirmed it: 8 mg twice a day for three days surrounding tx.  I'm pretty sensitive to new medication, so it kinda made me crazy (I felt like my heart was going to "explode").  I took the proper dose for two days, but eased off on the third. When I saw my oncologist before the next round, I asked her about taking less and she said there wasn't a lot of research on it, so not to mess around with it, at least on the day prior and the day of treatment, and to self-monitor for difficulty breathing.  So I dutifully took the 16 mg for two days and only took 4 mg the third day.  And I was fine (but wired, of course). It is kind of wild to me that there is this blanket dosage given, no matter what you weigh and how you respond.  The Taxotere manufacturers' website recommends 16 mg / day.  I met a woman who said she had a bad reaction to the Taxotere and stayed on the decadron for TEN days!  I would be bouncing off the walls...
